citation.article-title: Aeromonas bestiarum sp. nov., formerly genomospecies DNA group 2 A. hydrophila, a new species isolated from non-human sources.
citation.source: Medical Microbiology Letters : an international journal for rapid communications on all aspects of medical and clinical microbiology

p.s: Designation of Aeromonas bestiarum sp. nov.
Aeromonas bestiarum (bes.ti.a' rum, derived from the Latin noun, bestiarum, meaning of beasts (whether wild or domestic))
This designation was selected since a majority of the strains originated from veterinary and environmental sources (73%).
The type strain of this species is designated as ATCC 51108T (formerly CDC 9533-76, CIP 7430, Popoff C218), previously deposited at ATCC in 1992 by F.

This species has a unique biochemical profile of negative reactions for: utilization of D-L lactate, acid production from sorbitol, and a positive reaction for utilization of urocanic acid (25°C and 35°C±1°)(Table 3).
Of the 9 confirmed A. bestiarum strains, only two (27%) were isolated from human sources.
Whether or not these 2 strains were associated with patent clinical infection is not known.
To examine their potential role in human infections, it will be important to isolate and study a large number of A. bestiarum strains in a suitable animal model.

In a recent study of 80 hybridized Aeromonas strains that established baseline data on the pathogenicity of 12 Aeromonas genomospecies in outbred mice, five HG 2 strains from environmental and animal sources were tested (9).
They ranked seventh in decreasing order of relative virulence between HGs 1and 3.
HG1 A. hvdrophila displayed the second highest virulence potential of 12 genomospecies tested and HG3 A. salmonicida strains were ranked just below HG 2 A. bestiarum.

This suggests a possible low virulence potential for humans among A. bestiarum strains and may in part explain the low incidence with which they are isolated in relation to the large numbers of clinical Aeromonas strains found among HGs 1,4 and 8 as reported in previous studies(2,5, 10).
